## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 270, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 358, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|> At a college, the students choose exactly one of tennis, hockey or netball to play. The table shows the numbers of students in Year 1 and Year 2 at the college playing each of these sports. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 120, 732, 196]]<|/det|>
TennisHockeyNetball
Year 1162212
Year 2241828
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 208, 858, 227]]<|/det|> One student is chosen at random from the 120 students. Events \(X\) and \(N\) are defined as follows: <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 240, 376, 258]]<|/det|> \(X\): the student is in Year 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 271, 390, 289]]<|/det|> \(N\): the student plays netball. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 303, 144, 320]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 275, 320]]<|/det|> Find \(\mathrm{P}(X|N)\) . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 303, 920, 320]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 395, 146, 413]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 275, 413]]<|/det|> Find \(\mathrm{P}(N|X)\) . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 395, 920, 413]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 488, 144, 505]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 488, 615, 505]]<|/det|> Determine whether or not \(X\) and \(N\) are independent events. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 488, 920, 505]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 642, 920, 676]]<|/det|> One of the students who plays netball takes 8 shots at goal. On each shot, the probability that she will succeed is 0.15, independently of all other shots. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 689, 146, 707]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 689, 692, 707]]<|/det|> Find the probability that she succeeds on fewer than 3 of these shots. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 689, 920, 707]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 720, 917, 737]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
In a class of 21 students, there are 10 violinists, 6 guitarists and 5 pianists. A group of 7 is to be chosen from these 21 students. The group will consist of 4 violinists, 2 guitarists and 1 pianist.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 120, 144, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 544, 138]]<|/det|>
In how many ways can the group of 7 be chosen?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
On another occasion a group of 5 will be chosen from the 21 students. The group must contain at least 2 violinists, at least 1 guitarist and at most 1 pianist.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 146, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
In how many ways can the group of 5 be chosen?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|> Teams of 15 runners took part in a charity run last Saturday. The times taken, in minutes, to complete the course by the runners from the Falcons and the runners from the Kites are shown in the table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 118, 888, 170]]<|/det|>
Falcons383942444648505152565859646976
Kites324040454748525458595960616365
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 184, 144, 202]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 183, 920, 217]]<|/det|> Draw a back-to-back stem-and-leaf diagram to represent this information, with the Falcons on the left-hand side. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 201, 920, 219]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 695, 146, 712]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 694, 717, 714]]<|/det|> Find the median and the interquartile range of the times for the Falcons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 695, 920, 712]]<|/det|> [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Let \(x\) and \(y\) denote the times, in minutes, of a runner from the Falcons and a runner from the Kites respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 118, 235, 135]]<|/det|>
It is given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 147, 789, 168]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma x = 792,\qquad \Sigma x^{2} = 43 504,\qquad \Sigma y = 783,\qquad \Sigma y^{2} = 42 223.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 144, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
Find the mean and the standard deviation of the times taken by all 30 runners from the two teams.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 197, 918, 215]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
In a game, players attempt to score a goal by kicking a ball into a net. The probability that Leno scores a goal is 0.4 on any attempt, independently of all other attempts. The random variable \(X\) denotes the number of attempts that it takes Leno to score a goal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 280, 152]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(X = 5)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 134, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 256, 146, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 311, 275]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(3 \leqslant X \leqslant 7)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 256, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 476, 181, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 476, 794, 495]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that Leno scores his second goal on or before his 5th attempt.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 476, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 410, 89]]<|/det|>
Leno has 75 attempts to score a goal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 146, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Use a suitable approximation to find the probability that Leno scores more than 28 goals but fewer than 35 goals.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
